body.p: Which of the following is not a function of the integumentary system?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The integumentary system helps regulate electrolytes through sweating.
Incorrect. The integumentary system thermoregulates through sweat.
Correct. The integumentary is not responsible for movement. The skeletal and muscular systems have that function.
Incorrect. There are sensory receptors located in the integumentary system.

body.p: Keratin and oil work together to make the skin _______

feedback.p: Incorrect. The receptor cells allow for sensory reception.
Incorrect. Sweat assists in thermoregulation.
Incorrect. Vitamin D is secreted from a steroid in the skin.
Correct. Keratin and oils combine to give skin its water resistance.

body.p: A burn can be caused by which of the following?

feedback.p: This is only partially correct. This is not the only cause of burns.
This is only partially correct. This is not the only cause of burns.
This is only partially correct. This is not the only cause of burns.
Correct. All three of these can cause burns.

body.p: Which of these is the result of plugged sebaceous glands?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Psoriasis is caused by an overproduction of skin cells.
Correct. Acne is caused when sebum is clogged in the sebaceous gland.
Incorrect. Bed sores can be caused by extended pressure on an area.
Incorrect. Melanoma can be caused by UV radiation.

body.p: The skin consists of how many layers?

input.choice: Three: the epidermis, dermis and muscle
Three: the epidermis, dermis and hypodermis

feedback.p: Incorrect. There is more than one layer of skin.
Correct. These are the two layers of skin.
Incorrect. The muscles are not part of the integumentary system.
Incorrect. The epidermis, dermis and hypodermis are layers, but the hypodermis is subcutaneous, meaning "under the skin."

body.p: Which of the following is found in the hypodermis?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Sweat glands are located in the dermis.
Incorrect. Hair follicles are located in the dermis.
Correct. Adipose tissue is found in the hypodermis.
Incorrect. Melanocytes are found in the epidermis.

body.p: Vitamin D would be classified on which level of organization?

feedback.p: Correct. Vitamin D is a molecule.
Incorrect. Vitamin D is too small to be seen with a regular light microscope.
Incorrect. Vitamin D is not a type of tissue.
Incorrect. Vitamin D is not an organ.

body.p: Keratin gives nails, hair and skin which property?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Melanin gives skin its color.
Incorrect. Elastin gives skin its elasticity.
Incorrect. Sensory receptors give skin its sensitivity to the environment.
Correct. Keratin gives skin its water-resistant property.

body.p: Keratin is a:

feedback.p: Incorrect. DNA and RNA are nucleic acids.
Incorrect. Sugars and glycogen are carbohydrates.
Incorrect. Steroids and fatty acids are lipids.
Correct. Keratin is a type of structural protein.

body.p: Vitamin D production relies on:

feedback.p: Incorrect. Heat is not required to activate the vitamin D precursor.
Incorrect. Cold is not required to activate the vitamin D precursor.
Correct. UV radiation is required to activate the vitamin D precursor.
Incorrect. Calcitriol is the active form of vitamin D.

body.p: Which of the following is a function of vitamin D?

feedback.p: Correct. Vitamin D is needed for the small intestine to efficiently absorb calcium.
Incorrect. Vitamin D is not needed for magnesium absorption.
Incorrect. Vitamin D is required for calcium absorption, not excretion.
Incorrect. Vitamin D is not needed for magnesium excretion.

body.p: A type of dendritic cell found in the skin is a _________.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Keratinocytes are dead cells that form the majority of the epidermis.
Incorrect. Basal cells are stem cells, not immune cells.
Correct. Langerhans cells are immune cells of the skin.
Incorrect. Merkel cells are responsible for light touch sensation.

body.p: The bottom layer of the epidermis and the top layer of the dermis interconnect. Which of the following is a correct description of this?

input.choice: The epidermis has desmosomes and the dermis has papillae.
The epidermis has papillae and the dermis has desmosomes.
The epidermis has adipose tissue and the dermis has papillae.
The epidermis has papillae and the dermis has keratinocytes.

feedback.p: Correct. The lower level of the epidermis has desmosomes and the dermis has papillae.
Incorrect. The epidermis has desmosomes and the dermis has papillae.
Incorrect. The hypodermis has adipose tissue.
Incorrect. Keratinocytes are located in the epidermis and papillae are located in the dermis.

body.p: ______ is the most common type of skin cancer and _______ is the most fatal type.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Melanoma is not the most common skin cancer,it is the most fatal type of skin cancer.
Correct. Basal cell carcinoma is the most common, while melanoma is the most fatal.
Incorrect. Melanoma is the most fatal type of skin cancer, but squamous cell carcinoma is not the most common type.
Incorrect. Melanoma is the most fatal type of skin cancer, not the most common.

body.p: Which type of cancer affects the keratinocytes?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Basal cell carcinoma affects the cells of the stratum basale.
Correct. Squamous cell carcinoma affects the keratinocytes.
Incorrect. Melanoma affects the melanocytes.
Incorrect. One of these cancers affects the keratinocytes.

body.p: Which of the following are only found in the hypodermis?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Macrophages can be found in the dermis and hypodermis.
Correct. Adipose tissue is only found in the hypodermis.
Incorrect. Epithelial cells are found in the epidermis.
Incorrect. Fibroblasts are found in the dermis.

body.p: Which type(s) of tissue make up the dermis?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Epithelial tissue is found in the epidermis.
Partially correct. Areolar tissue is one type of connective tissue found in the dermis.
Partially correct. Dense irregular connective tissue is one type of connective tissue found in the dermis.
Correct. Both of these are types of connective tissue found in the dermis.

body.p: What is the main cause of stretch marks?

input.choice: The collagen and elastin in the dermis are damaged by the sun.
The dermis is stretched beyond the collagen and elastin fibers' ability to distend.
The epidermis is stretched beyond the collagen and elastin fibers' ability to distend, and tears.
The hypodermis is stretched beyond the ability of the fibroblasts to distend.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Sun damage will cause wrinkles, not stretchmarks.
Correct. Stretch marks occur when there is a lack of support from the extracellular matrix proteins and there is tearing in the dermis.
Incorrect. The extracellular matrix proteins are found in the dermis. If the epidermis tears, you risk an open wound.
Incorrect. The fibroblasts of the dermis create these extracellular proteins to supply support.

body.p: Why do stretch marks usually start out with a reddish tint?

input.choice: Byproducts of collagen break down and turn the skin red.
Byproducts of elastin break down and turn the skin red.
The red from the blood vessels shows through.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The stretching of the skin does not stimulate melanocytes.
Incorrect. The breakdown of collagen does not create a reddish tint.
Incorrect. The breakdown of elastin does not create a reddish tint.
Correct. The stretching of the skin causes it to become thin and the red of the blood can be seen.

body.p: A suntan is an indication of:

input.choice: The body preparing to fight skin cancer.
The body protecting itself from the heat of the sun.
The body protecting itself from UV radiation damage.

feedback.p: Incorrect. A tan is the body’s way of preventing skin cancer and indicating that there is too much radiation.
Incorrect. It is protecting the body from the radiation of the sun.
Incorrect. Tanning is a defence mechanism of the body to protect from the sun's radiation.
Correct. Melanin, which causes the tan color, is produced in response to UV radiation.

body.p: Darker skin pigments are the result of:

feedback.p: Incorrect. Most people have the same number of melanocytes.
Correct. The darker coloring is the result of more melanin production.
Incorrect. Lysosomes will break down the color-containing cells.
Incorrect. These cells receive pigment from the melanocytes.

body.p: How does the stratum spinosum increase strength and flexibility?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Although this layer contains macrophages, they increase protection from microorganisms.
Correct. The protruding desmosomes of this layer give it its spiny appearance and its extra strength and flexibility.
Incorrect. The stratum granulosum contains lamellar granules.
Incorrect. Merkel cells are a type of sensory receptor.

body.p: The stratum corneum provides protection by:

input.choice: Creating a thin, clear layer of protection
Creating a thin, flexible layer of reproducing cells
Creating a thick layer of dead, water-resistant cells

feedback.p: Incorrect. The stratum spinosum creates strength with desmosomes.
Incorrect. The stratum lucidum creates a thin clear layer in thick skin.
Incorrect. The stratum basale is a thin layer of reproducing cells.
Correct. The stratum corneum provides protection by having a think layer of dead, water-resistant cells.

body.p: Why would there be an extra layer of epidermis on the palms?

input.choice: The extra layer of flat, densely packed cells allows for extra protection against the environment.
The extra layer of flat, densely packed cells allows for extra sensory receptors to interact with the environment.
It allows for more phagocytes to protect against microorganisms.
This layer is spiny and adds extra flexibility to the epidermis.

feedback.p: Correct. The stratum lucidum provides an extra layer of protection for the palmsof the hands and soles of the feet.
Incorrect. The thicker layer does not add extra sensory receptors.
Incorrect. The extra layer does not add more phagocytes.
Incorrect. This describes the stratum spinosum.

body.p: Which layer of the epidermis is a single-celled layer that is constantly undergoing mitosis?

feedback.p: Correct. The stratum basale is the layer that is constantly dividing.
Incorrect. the stratum spinosum contains keratinocytes and Langerhans cells.
Incorrect. The stratum corneum is composed primarily of dead cells.
Incorrect. The stratum lucidum is unique to areas with thick skin.

body.p: Which of the following does not describe the composition of the papillary layer?

input.choice: A mesh of collagen fibers and elastin fibers
Interspersed with lymph ducts and sensory

feedback.p: Incorrect. Phagocytes are likely to be found in the papillary layer.
Correct. This mesh of fibers gives the reticular layer its name.
Incorrect. This accurately describes the papillary layer.
Incorrect. This accurately describes the papillary layer.

body.p: The reticular layer contains a lot of:

feedback.p: Incorrect. Keratinocytes are found in the epidermis.
Incorrect. Adipose tissue is found in the hypodermis.
Correct. The reticular layer contains bundles of collagen fibers.
Incorrect. Dermal papillae are extensions of the papillary layer.

body.p: What features of the papillary layer allow it to protect the body from microorganisms?

feedback.p: Partially correct. Lymph ducts are just one of the structures that help the papillary layer protect the body from microorganisms.
Partially correct. Phagocytes are just one of the structures that help the papillary layer protect the body from microorganisms.
Incorrect. Sensory receptors are part of the nervous system.
Correct. Both of these structures help the papillary layer protect the body from microorganisms.

body.p: What feature of the dermis adds to the strength and flexibility of the skin?

input.choice: The net-like mesh of collagen and elastin

feedback.p: Incorrect. The phagocytes protect against infection.
Correct. The mesh of collagen and elastin add strength and flexibility.
Incorrect. The desmosomes of the epidermis add strength.
Incorrect. The interspersed lymph nodes protect against infection.

body.p: The hypodermis is vasculated, which means what?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Vascularization is not related to adipose tissue.
Incorrect. Vascularization is not related to areolar tissue.
Incorrect. Vascularization is not related to collagen fibers.
Correct. A vascularized tissue has blood vessels.

body.p: Why did our bodies evolve to store fat in our hypodermis?

input.choice: To assist in regulating body temperature by lowering our temperature
In case of a time of famine
It did not evolve this way; storing fat has always been a health risk

feedback.p: Incorrect. Adipose tissue helps to insulate the body.
Correct. Our bodies evolved to store fat in case there was a famine.
Incorrect. High amounts of fat will increase heart problems.
Incorrect. Our sedentary lifestyle and poor diet lead to the storage of fat being a health risk.

body.p: What does hair get its color from?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The dermis is a layer of the skin.
Incorrect. Keratin is a waterproofing protein that can harden.
Correct. Melanin pigment will color the hair.
Incorrect. Sebum is a moisturizer secreted by sebaceous glands.

body.p: What is the function of sebum?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Nails provide protection from mechanical damage.
Incorrect. Thermoregulation is a function of the sweat glands.
Incorrect. Sensory receptors are structures such as Merkel discs.
Correct. Sebum is an oil to moisturize the dead skin cells.

body.p: Which of the following is not a layer of the hair bulb?

feedback.p: Correct. The follicle describes the entire structure that processes hair.
Incorrect. The medulla is the innermost layer of the hair bulb.
Incorrect. The cortex is the second layer of the hair bulb.
Incorrect. The cuticle is the outer layer of the hair bulb.

body.p: What is an accurate description of the glassy membrane?

input.choice: Does not surround the entire hair strand
Made up of basal cells at the base of the hair root
Thick, clear connective tissue sheath covering the hair root

feedback.p: Incorrect. This more accurately describes the medulla of the hair bulb.
Incorrect. This more accurately describes the internal root sheath.
Incorrect. This more accurately describes the external root sheath.
Correct. The glassy membrane is a thick, clear connective tissue sheath that covers the hair root.

body.p: If someone stood too close to a fire and singed their eyelashes and eyebrows, what problems may they have?

input.choice: Dust may get in their eyes more frequently.
More sweat may get in their eyes.
More allergens may get in their eyes.

feedback.p: Partially correct. This is only one result that may occur.
Partially correct. This is only one result that may occur.
Partially correct. This is only one result that may occur.
Correct. All of these situations may occur.

body.p: Which is the longest stage of hair growth?

feedback.p: Correct. Anagen can last from two to five years.
Incorrect. This phase only lasts one to two weeks.
Incorrect. This phase only lasts five to six weeks.
Incorrect. Anagen lasts the longest.

body.p: Hair loss occurs ________

input.choice: when not enough melanin is produced.
when not enough catagen is produced.
when more hair is shed than replaced.

feedback.p: Incorrect. A lack of melanin causes loss of hair color, not hair loss.
Incorrect. Catagen is a stage of hair growth, not a chemical.
Correct. When more hair is shed than replaced, the result will be hair loss.
Incorrect. An increased sensitivity to DHT will actually cause hair loss.

body.p: Which of the following consists of live cells?

feedback.p: Incorrect. This is the white area of the nail and does not have living cells.
Incorrect. This is the most distal part of the nail.
Incorrect. The nail body consists of densely packed dead cells.
Correct. The nail root has the matrix, which consists of living cells.

body.p: The function of the nail folds is to ________

feedback.p: Incorrect. The nail matrix in the nail bed produces new cells.
Incorrect. The lunula is the white part of the nail body.
Correct. The nail folds help anchor the nail body.
Incorrect. The entire nail body protects the hyponychium.

body.p: Which gland functions primarily to regulate body temperature?

feedback.p: Correct. Merocrine glands are throughout the skin surface and regulate the body temperature.
Incorrect. Apocrine glands are associated with hair follicles.
Incorrect. Sebaceous glands produce oil.
Incorrect. Salivary glands are responsible for producing saliva.

body.p: Acne is not normally seen before puberty because ________

input.choice: apocrine glands do not become active until puberty.
eccrine glands do not become active until puberty.
sweat glands do not become active until puberty.
sebaceous glands do not become active until puberty.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Apocrine glands do become active at puberty, but they do not cause acne.
Incorrect. Eccrine glands are active throughout life and do not cause acne.
Incorrect. There are different types of sweat glands, but they do not cause acne.
Correct. Clogged sebaceous glands result in acne, and these glands do not become active until puberty.

body.p: What is the function of fibroblasts in wound healing?

input.choice: Engulf foreign matter to prevent infection
Divide rapidly to replace damaged cells
Form blood clots to stop bleeding

feedback.p: Incorrect. Macrophages engulf foreign matter.
Correct. Fibroblasts secrete collagen fibers.
Incorrect. The basal stem cells divide rapidly.
Incorrect. Blood clots are not formed by fibroblasts.

body.p: Scar formation is a natural process, but can interfere with the regeneration of:

feedback.p: Partially correct. Because a scar is a dense fibrous structure there are few cells, so this is just one of several accessory structures that cannot regenerate.
Partially correct. Because a scar is a dense fibrous structure there are few cells, so this is just one of several accessory structures that cannot regenerate.
Partially correct. Because a scar is a dense fibrous structure there are few cells, so this is just one of several accessory structures that cannot regenerate.
Correct. Because a scar is a dense fibrous structure there are few cells, affecting the ability of several accessory structures to regenerate.

body.p: Which of the following can cause a burn?

feedback.p: Partially correct. This is only one cause of a burn.
Partially correct. This is only one cause of a burn.
Partially correct. This is only one cause of a burn.
Correct. These can all cause burns to the skin.

body.p: Which type of burn will require a skin graft?

feedback.p: Incorrect. First-degree burns only damage the epidermis and can be locally repaired.
Incorrect. Second-degree burns may blister, but can be repaired locally.
Correct. These full-thickness burns have too much local damage to repair themselves.
Partially correct. This is just one type of burn that cannot repair itself because there is too much local damage.

body.p: Which of the following isnota true statement?

input.choice: Apocrine glands become active at puberty.
Cells divide less frequently and result in thinner skin as a person ages.
Sweat glands secrete a reduced amount as a result of puberty.
The breakdown of elastin causes wrinkling of the skin.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Apocrine glands do become active during puberty.
Incorrect. Cells do divide less frequently in as a person ages, resulting in thinner skin.
Correct. Sweat glands increase secretion during puberty and decrease secretion with age.
Incorrect. The breakdown of elastin does cause wrinkling of the skin.

body.p: Why does the skin get thinner as people age?

input.choice: The basal cells do not reproduce as frequently
The reduction and redistribution of fat

feedback.p: Incorrect. The cross-linking of elastin reduces resilience.
Correct. The skin is constantly shedding, so if new cells are not produced as frequently, the skin gets thinner.
Incorrect. Changes to the adipose tissue affect the hypodermis.
Incorrect. The inactivity of melanocytes results in paler skin.

body.p: Why do fair-skinned people develop reddish skin color during an exercise routine?

input.choice: The blood vessels dilate, bringing the red color to the surface.
The blood vessels constrict, bringing the red color to the surface.
The adipose tissue breaks down, causing a red color.
The glands open to sweat, causing a red color.

feedback.p: Correct. The dilated blood vessels can result in a reddish color.
Incorrect. During exercise the blood vessels dilate.
Incorrect. The breakdown of adipose tissue does not result in the red coloring.
Incorrect. Sweat is a colorless excretion.

body.p: How do goosebumps contribute to thermoregulation?

input.choice: They lower body temperature by activating sweat glands.
They lower body temperature by increasing the surface area of the skin to release more heat.
They reduce heat loss by activating the adipose tissue for insulation.
They reduce heat loss by working with erect hairs to trap heat close to the body.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Goosebumps to not play a role in cooling the body.
Incorrect. Goosebumps do not play a role in cooling the body.
Incorrect. Goosebumps do help insulate, but they are not activating the adipose tissue.
Correct. By holding warm air close to the body, they help insulate it and reduce heat loss.

body.p: The function of the free nerve ending is to ________

feedback.p: Incorrect. Merkel discs sense pressure.
Incorrect. Lamellated corpuscles sense vibration.
Incorrect. Tactile corpuscles sense pressure.
Correct. Free nerve endings sense pain.

body.p: What do lamellated corpuscles sense?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Pain is sensed by free nerve endings.
Incorrect. Temperature is sensed by free nerve endings.
Correct. Lamellated discs sense vibrations.
Incorrect. Merkel discs sense light touch.

body.p: Jaundice is a yellow coloring of the skin that can be symptomatic of what?

feedback.p: Incorrect. A symptom of hypothermia is a blue tint.
Incorrect. A symptom of carbon monoxide poisoning is a red color.
Correct. If the liver is not working correctly, then bilirubin can accumulate, making the skin look yellow.
Incorrect. To much copper will result in a bronze coloration.

body.p: A healthy fair-skinned person usually has cheeks tinted which color?

feedback.p: Incorrect. A bronze color indicates too much copper.
Incorrect. A white tint indicates a sudden lack of oxygen.
Incorrect. A person with blue-tinted cheeks may be cold or suffering from a lack oxygen.
Correct. A healthy person has rosy tinted cheeks because of the red color of the hemoglobin combined with oxygen.
